text: i just spent a chunk of time trying to reproduce with modules and wasn’t able to. were there any errors or messages in the terminal while watching the files?
what version of the CLI are you using?

I’m trying to follow along with the HubSpot CMS Boilerplate `README`. when I run the command `npx @HubSpot/create-cms-project --ssh <directory>` I get this error:
>‘Cloning into \‘/[pathname]\‘...
git@github.com: Permission denied (publickey).
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.  Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
’
Am I missing something?

I had a similar error when first setting up a portal. My problem was i was using the dev portal number (the one with my app/token) in the place where i should have been using the client's portal number.
Hey <@U3T21PDBK>! Try removing the `--ssh` and see if it works
worked!
:raised_hands: sorry, we will update README

Getting started with local dev beta and have some thoughts and questions:

1) am I right that we can't upload svg's into the DM even with the recent images support?


2) what's to stop me from deving locally (with the ol' hubl-server and all my hot-reloading and all), push to DEV (sandbox) for staging, then some kind of deploy action (git or otherwise) to deploy to PROD? Trying to asses the feasibility of this work flow
Ok, I think I am going to scratch the second question on that. trying to wrangle the local-hubl-server seems like an extra step I don't want to deal with at this point
but oppinions still welcome
for #2, that seems like the best workflow to me…
<@U3T21PDBK> Right? I am going to get the workflow laid out by the talk given at inbound (aka git deployment) and then try and layer on the local-hubl-server
I think trying to get it all at once might confuse my brain a little because the file structures are a little different in the hubl server than the DM
it only makes sense to use the local server… having to go back and forth between a browser and refresh would not be on the table for me
true that
those local hubl server file structures haven't ever really made sense to me, but I got it working well enough to GSD

the file structure of the local hubl server is outdated so yeah it can be confusing to use it with the current DM structure. currently there is no official way of connecting the local server with the CLI tooling, but it is something we are talking about
<@U3T21PDBK> picky picky picky! :wink:
<@UEKMY50SU> Thanks! It would be amazing to have this in the mix

Ok, so another piece that I think should be raised here: There's no way to upload coded html template files. I ran into this when using the FTP function and basically would dev locally, then upload the html for my template and copy it into a new html "template" file in the DM

*edited* read the thread. All my bad.

either an html file wont get recognized as a template (ie I can generate a page from it) OR it errors because it "doesn't include" those header and footer standards, even though I am using {% extends "base.html" %} which does have these
basically the same way it functioned with ftp
like yo:
are you including the template metadata comment at the top? see <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/blob/master/src/templates/blog-post.html#L1> as an example
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/tools/local-development-reference> (see the "Local Template Format" section)
I just caught that. Thanks <@UEKMY50SU>
<@UEKMY50SU> what about the erroring because the header and footer includes are in the base.html?
ie extending?
hold the phone...lemme try one thing
Ok, that error was my bad. wrong path to the base.html
agreed, the CLI tooling has been amazing so far, i have no doubt that the local hubl server will deliver. Thank y’all!

Sorry for blowin up the local-dev-beta channel here...a few of my modules are using hubdb in my production environment. Is there a clean way to pull that data across portals into my dev environment? API perhaps? I am not super savy with pulling data using API's but happy to figure it out if this is how most folks would handle this. Or if there is another more preferable way...
